translated: The Monastic Code of the Elders
The Great Analysis
The chapter on offenses entailing confession
The sub-chapter on the precious things
The training rule on Nanda

original: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: tena samayena buddhaḥ bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.

original: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā nando bhagavato mātucchāputto abhirūpo hoti dassanīyo pāsādiko caturaṅgulomako bhagavatā.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena āyasmā nandaḥ bhagavataḥ mātucchā putto abhirūpaḥ hoti dassanīyaḥ pāsādiko catur aṅgulomakaḥ bhagavatā
translated: At that time Venerable Nanda, the Buddha’s cousin, was good-looking, and he was well proportioned and attractive, with body hair that grew in the right direction and was of the right texture, and he was the Buddha’s equal in appearance.

original: So sugatacīvarappamāṇaṁ cīvaraṁ dhāreti.🔽Addasaṁsu kho therā bhikkhū āyasmantaṁ nandaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ sugata cīvara ppamāṇam cīvaram dhāreti  kho therāḥ bhikkhū āyasmantam nandam dūratas uva āgacchanta
translated: He wore robes that were the Buddha’s size.
The senior monks saw him coming and thought,🔽“The Buddha is coming.”
They got up from their seats.

original: Te upagate jānitvā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
analyzed: te upagate jānitvā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti
translated: When they realized it was Nanda, they complained and criticized him,

original: “kathañhi nāma āyasmā nando sugatacīvarappamāṇaṁ cīvaraṁ dhāressatī”ti …pe…
analyzed: katham hi nāma āyasmā nandaḥ sugata cīvara ppamāṇam cīvaram dhāressati iti pe
translated: “How could Venerable Nanda wear robes that are the Buddha’s size?” …

original: “saccaṁ kira tvaṁ, nanda, sugatacīvarappamāṇaṁ cīvaraṁ dhāresī”ti?
analyzed: saccam kira tva nanda sugata cīvara ppamāṇam cīvaram dhāresi iti
translated: “Is it true, Nanda, that you do this?”
“It’s true, Sir.”
The Buddha rebuked him …🔽“And, monks, this is how it should be done. …

original: kathañhi nāma tvaṁ, nanda, sugatacīvarappamāṇaṁ cīvaraṁ dhāressasi.
analyzed: katham hi nāma tva nanda sugata cīvara ppamāṇam cīvaram dhāressasi
translated: “How could you do this?

analyzed: neta nanda appasannānam vā pasādāya pe
translated: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …

original: evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ uddiseyyātha—
analyzed: evam ca pana bhikkhave imam sikkhāpadam uddiseyyātha
translated: And, monks, this is how you should recite this training rule:

original: “Yo pana bhikkhu sugatacīvarappamāṇaṁ cīvaraṁ kārāpeyya atirekaṁ vā, chedanakaṁ pācittiyaṁ.
analyzed: yaḥ pana bhikkhu sugata cīvara ppamāṇam cīvaram kārāpeyya atirekam vā chedanakam pācittiya
translated: ‘If a monk has a robe made that is the standard robe measure of the Buddha, or larger, it is to be cut up. He commits an offense entailing confession.’”

original: Tatridaṁ sugatassa sugatacīvarappamāṇaṁ—dīghaso nava vidatthiyo, sugatavidatthiyā; tiriyaṁ cha vidatthiyo.
analyzed: tatridam sugatassa sugata cīvara ppamāṇa dīghasaḥ nava vidatthiyaḥ sugata vidatthiyā tiriyam cha
translated: The standard robe measure of the Buddha: nine standard handspans long and six wide.

analyzed: idam sugatassa sugata cīvara ppamāṇam ti
translated: This is the standard robe measure of the Buddha.
If a monk:

analyzed: yaḥ ya ādisaḥ pe  bhikkhū ti
translated: if he is the first offender,🔽monk:

analyzed: pe ayam imasmin atthe adhippetaḥ bhikkhu iti
translated: the term “monk” here is used in the sense of one who is fully ordained.
The standard robe measure of the Buddha:

original: dīghaso nava vidatthiyo, sugatavidatthiyā; tiriyaṁ cha vidatthiyo.
analyzed: nava vidatthiyaḥ sugata vidatthiyā tiriyam cha vidatthiyaḥ
translated: nine standard handspans long and six wide.
Has a robe made:

original: karoti vā kārāpeti vā, payoge dukkaṭaṁ.
translated: if he makes one or has one made, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
When he gets it, it is to be cut up, and he is then to confess an offense entailing confession.

original: Attanā vippakataṁ attanā pariyosāpeti, āpatti pācittiyassa.
analyzed: attanā vippakatam attanā pariyosāpeti āpatti pācittiyassa
translated: If he finishes what he has begun himself, he commits an offense entailing confession.

original: Attanā vippakataṁ parehi pariyosāpeti, āpatti pācittiyassa.🔽Parehi vippakataṁ attanā pariyosāpeti, āpatti pācittiyassa.
analyzed: attanā vippakatam parehi pariyosāpeti āpatti pācittiyassa  parehi vippakatam attanā pariyosāpeti āpatti pācittiyassa
translated: If he finishes what he has begun by others, he commits an offense entailing confession.🔽If he finishes what has been begun by others himself, he commits an offense entailing confession.

original: Parehi vippakataṁ parehi pariyosāpeti, āpatti pācittiyassa.🔽Aññassatthāya karoti vā kārāpeti vā, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
analyzed: parehi vippakatam parehi pariyosāpeti āpatti pācittiyassa  aññassa atthāya karoti vā kārāpeti vā āpatti dukkaṭassa
translated: If he finishes what has been begun by others by others, he commits an offense entailing confession.🔽If he makes one or has one made for the benefit of someone else, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

original: Aññena kataṁ paṭilabhitvā paribhuñjati, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
analyzed: aññena katam paṭilabhitvā paribhuñjati āpatti dukkaṭassa
translated: If he uses one obtained from someone else after cutting it down, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
There is no offense
if he makes one that is too small;
if he uses one obtained from someone else after cutting it down;

original: vitānaṁ vā bhūmattharaṇaṁ vā sāṇipākāraṁ vā bhisiṁ vā bibbohanaṁ vā karoti,
analyzed: vitānam vā bhūmattharaṇam vā sāṇi pākāram vā bhisim vā bibbohanam vā karoti
translated: if he makes a canopy, a floor cover, a cloth screen, a bed surround, or a bed valance;
if he is insane;

analyzed: ādikammikassa ati  nanda sikkhāpadam niṭṭhitam dasama  rata na vaggaḥ navamaḥ
translated: if he is the first offender.🔽The training rule on Nanda, the tenth, is finished.
The ninth sub-chapter on precious things is finished.🔽The summary:

original: Rañño ca ratanaṁ santaṁ,🔽sūci mañcañca tūlikaṁ;
analyzed: rañño ca ratanam santa  sūci mañcañca tūlika
translated: Royal, and precious things,🔽needle, bed, and cotton-wool;
Sitting mat, and itch,
and rainy season, and by the Well-Gone.

original: Uddiṭṭhā kho, āyasmanto, dvenavuti pācittiyā dhammā.
analyzed: uddiṭṭhā kho āyasmantaḥ dvenavuti pācittiyāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: The two hundred and ninety rules for resolving legal issues have been recited.
I ask the resident monks:
‘Are you pure in this?’
A second time I ask:
‘Are you pure in this?’
A third time I ask:
‘Are you pure in this?’

analyzed: parisuddhā itthā ayasmantaḥ tasmai tuṇhī evam etam dhārayāmi iti
translated: Since there is silence, you are pure in this. I will remember it thus.”
The minor rules are finished.
The chapter on offenses entailing confession is finished.
